Posts.Content: BJB1 wrote: This forum was a miracle find for me last November when my DCIS was discovered.  Without the ladies on here, I would have made the wrong decisions.  And I am very grateful. BUT I never read beyond this.  Reconstruction seemed so far off.  All I wanted was to know about DCIS and DIEP recon.  Please be sure to read about fat harvesting now.  Knowing the whole story from beginning to end is vital in making the right decisions for yourselves from step one. For me, the decision making was worse than the cancer.  It caused more stress than finding out about the invasion.  But now that most of my decisions are behind me, I am so grateful to have the ability to do research, question my doctors, and count on you for support and education. Wishing each and every one of you the best, BJB Dx 11/2010, DCIS, Stage 0, Grade 3, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 11:42PM BJB1 wrote: I had my first lumpetomy Nov 19 and just got word today that I will have to go back under.  I have 4 areas with "dirty margins."  North, east, west, and south.  My surgeon suggests either choice:  a second lumpectomy or a mastectomy.  How do I make this decision?  I have been reading the different forums of this site, but I still can not decide.  I have DCIS with necrosis.  There were 2 suspicious calcium deposits, far enough apart to require almost 2 inches of mass removed already.  I began as a 38 B.  (If I weren't ovrweight, I would probably measure in as a 34 b.)  I have an aspiration and another mammo scheduled for Wednesday.  At 63, both girls slope downward.  Would a reconstructive breast be too perky?  A mastectomy seems a long way to go to clear just 4 more small spots, but the surgeon made it clear that my right breast will probably be quite deformed.  And with a follow up of radiation, any future reconstruction is more problematic.  Do I understand that correctly? What problems does a double lumpectomy cause?  Right now I am very swollen and and a little sore, but nothing that I can't handle.  I am having surgery at Brigham / Dana Farber (Boston) so I am in excellent hands either way. Any and all comments would be appreciated. BJB  Boston

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 04:58PM BJB1 wrote: I had my first lumpectomy Nov 19 with general anethesia.  I woke up remebering nothing other than being in pre-op.  And now I can't even remember post-op!!  Because I had orthopedic surgery a few years ago, I knew to tell the nurses and the doc to make sure they told everything to my husband who was in post op with me.  The orthopedic surgeon was stupid enough to have given me dfirections without anyone else hearing them!! I alos knew I would be very nauseous.  This time they gave me a patch to wear.  No nausea at all!  In fact, I could have gone out for a big lunch.  The gen anethesia  wore off a couple of hours later, but I never even needed a Tylenol.  Best of luck. BJB  Boston

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 03:32PM - edited Jul 12, 2011 03:33PM by BJB1 I am a gardener in Massachusetts.  We worry not only about mosquitos, but ticks as well.  I have tried it all.  The only real solution was REI's mosquito top.  I wish I had discovered it 20 years ago.  The top looks like a see-thru sweat shirt.  It is actually kind of cool.  The color of milk chocolate.  The hood can cover the entire face.  I use it all the time.  When I get closer to the streeet (and neighbors), I stop covering my face.  Everyone has been asking about it and I think the newest fashion craze is about to take off.  I was under the impression that lymphedema usually hit just the arms.  Is that not true?
